Jotham begins telling a parable where trees represent various people groups. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

tn.ref: When Jotham was told about this
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "When Jotham heard that Abimelech had murdered his brothers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a mountain. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: The trees once went out to anoint a king over them. For they said to the olive tree, 'Reign over us.'
tn.text: In this parable Jotham describes the trees doing things that humans do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: to anoint a king over them
tn.text: Here, to anoint with oil is a symbolic action that represents appointing a person to be king. AT: "to appoint a king to rule over all of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"Be our king"
Jotham continues telling his parable, where trees represent various people groups.

tn.ref: the olive tree said to them ... fig tree said to them
tn.text: In this parable, Jotham describes the trees as doing things that humans do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification|Personification]])

tn.ref: Should I give up my oil ... over the other trees?
tn.text: The olive tree is asking this question to refuse to be king. This question can be expressed as a statement. AT: "I will not give up my oil ... over the other trees." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion|Rhetorical Question]])
To "sway over" means to move back and forth in the wind. Here the tree uses this phrase to means to "rule over."

tn.ref: Should I give up my sweetness ... over the other trees?
tn.text: The fig tree is asking this question to refuse to be king. This question can be expressed as a statement. AT: "I will not give up my sweetness ... over the other trees." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion|Rhetorical Question]])

tn.ref: my sweetness and my good fruit
tn.text: The word "sweetness" is an abstract noun. It can be stated as an adjective that describes the fruit that grows on the tree. AT: "my good sweet fruit" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns|Abstract Nouns]])
Jotham continues telling his parable, where trees represent various people groups.

tn.ref: The trees said to the vine
tn.text: In this parable, Jotham describes the trees and the vine as doing things that humans do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Should I give up my new wine ... over the other trees?
tn.text: The vine is asking this question to refuse to be king. This question can be expressed as a statement. AT: "I will not give up my new wine ... over the other trees." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Thorns are sharp spikes or spurs that hurt. This bush has many sharp spikes along its branches.
Jotham continues telling his parable, where trees represent various people groups, and makes the application.

tn.ref: The thornbush said to the trees
tn.text: In this parable, Jotham describes the thornbush and the trees as doing things that humans do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: to anoint me as king over you
tn.text: To anoint someone with oil is a symbolic action that appoints a person to be king. AT: "to appoint me as your king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
The word "safety" is an abstract noun that can be expressed as an adjective. AT: "be safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: fire come out of the thornbush and let it burn up the cedars of Lebanon
tn.text: This means to let the thornbush burn so that it will burn the cedars.

tn.ref: then let fire come out of the thornbush
tn.text: The thornbush refers to itself as "the thornbush." AT: "then may fire come out from me, the thornbush" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This does not mean "at this moment," but is used to draw attention to the important point that follows.

tn.ref: if you have done well concerning Jerub Baal and his house, and if you have punished him as he deserves
tn.text: Jotham offered the possibility that what they did was good, but Jotham does not actually believe what they did was good. AT: "if you have done what is right and Jerub Baal deserved for you to kill all of his sons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
This is another name for Gideon. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:06:31| 6:32]].
Here "house" represents Gideon's family. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jotham makes the application to the situation at that time and place.

tn.ref: and to think that my father fought for you ... out of the hand of Midian
tn.text: Here Jotham is expressing that he cannot believe how badly the people of Shechem have treated Gideon and his family even after Gideon fought to save the people of Shechem.

tn.ref: out of the hand of Midian
tn.text: Here "hand" represents power or control. AT: "from the power of the Midianites" or "from the Midianites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an idiom. AT: "you have opposed" or "you have rebelled against" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.text: Jotham is speaking a curse. He speaks of Abimelech destroying the people of Shechem as if he would burn them with fire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
